Citizen journalists and bloggers seem to be rocking the vote - or maybe I should say rocking the boat - this political season.
This past week, WEEKEND EDITION's Sunday Soapbox blogger Jacob Soboroff attended the annual Webby Awards as a nominee.
He took advantage of his place on the red carpet to ask the guests about the role the Web and politics are playing during this year's presidential campaign.
Many were talking about Mayhill Fowler, a 61-year-old citizen journalist from the Huffington Post who broke two big campaign stories this season.
She also broke the ethical rules journalists is supposed to follow.
Jacob is in our New York studio to tell us more.
Hey, Jacob.
Hey, Liane.
Elaborate a little on who Mayhill Fowler is as well the stories and the rules she broke.
She's a 61-year-old housewife from northern California who had never had anything published before.
She put together two big stories this presidential election cycle.
One was from inside a fundraiser in San Francisco, where Barack Obama said some controversial statements about people clinging to religion and guns, and the other story happened quite recently.
It was at (unintelligible) South Dakota on a rope line where Mayhill came in Vanity Fair and the article that he wrote recently about the former president.
So, what's the big deal?
She talked to Bill Clinton, she recorded remarks that Senator Obama made.
What's the big deal?
Well, the first big deal is that at Senator Obama's fundraiser in San Francisco, this was an event that was technically off-the-record.
It was a fundraiser that was closed to the press and came out with some pretty controversial remarks that Senate Obama said that were in the headlines for quite some time after he said them.
In the case of Bill Clinton, Mayhill didn't disclose who she was and what she was doing on the rope line.
And when she asked President Clinton about the Vanity Fair article, he ended up saying some things that who knows if he would've said if he thought he was on the record so to speak.

Now, many journalists - I would venture to say all of them at least in the traditional media - feel it's unethical not to identify themselves when they're interviewing someone, and believe it's unethical to report on an event that is ostensibly off the record.
Are the rules changing for blogging journalism?
I think they are.
I come at this from an interesting perspective.
When I was in college I was an part-time advance man to Mayor Bloomberg and later to Howard Dean when he was running for president.
And we knew that the schedules that were put out on a daily basis, unless it was otherwise indicated, were open to the press.
You know, Mayhill could have asked the same question and not been a citizen journalist for the Huffington Post.

You know, nowadays anyone's a blogger, anyone's a vlogger and it could have ended up on the Internet anyways.
Don't you think it's not fair for bloggers to go to closed political events, not identify themselves and then put the remarks up on the Web site?
Oh, without a doubt.
I think if you have a credential you've got to wear it around your neck.

So, we're actually seeing, I think - or will see - a shift where politicians and campaign workers may approach these events differently going forward.
In other words, approach them as if everything they say is on the record.
Yeah, exactly.
Most traditional media organizations have a code of ethics - something that their journalists can refer to.
Is there a code on the Web?
No.
